content.description: Start on the lowest rail and make powerful moves up to the split in the boulder.The guidebook suggests you should top out using a high gaston above the split in the boulder.
content.location: One of the last boulders in the cluster of boulders downhill from Ebony and Ivory. The overhanging rails are a dead giveaway.

content.description:
Start at low point of right leaning crack, move up and right to end of crack, then follow series of crimps to triangular plate finish hold and top out. Walk off to right. 

 Climbed this line while supporting a friend working on Dia Bueno. Looked previously unclimbed, but will edit if climbed before. Nice problem with good holds. Probably V1, but could be V2 based on a half pad crimp or two midway up.
content.protection: One or two pads, decent landing.
content.location: Left of Mohela, just at edge of drop off.

content.description:
Starts low under small roof.   Big initial move to sloping pocket sets you up with a left hand crimp.    Another large throw gets you to a good jug where you begin to mantle onto the face of the climb. 

  Keep it together as you top out the tricky top of this boulder.
content.location: Facing down the hill. Look for boulder with large white streak on it, and very noticeable crimps lathered throughout it.

content.description: Start low in the two slots and move up to the rail. Gain the slopey lip of the boulder then traverse right until you can top out on big jugs.
content.location: One of the last boulders downhill in the cluster of boulders below Ebony and Ivory.

content.description: Start low with two pockets and move up the overhanging face using small crimps.
content.location: One of the first boulders downhill from the cliffline near Ebony and Ivory. Dia Bueno faces East.

content.description:
Cave Creek also has a small boulder field situated right below the brick attack area. 

  The problems here have been climbed by John Sherman way back in the day, and most of the recent development within the past 10 years has been locally fueled. 

  There isn't a lifetime of bouldering at cave creek, but enough for definitely a full day of pulling. All of the boulders are in close proximity and offer a great circuit.
